HOPKINS

BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 21,

SIR WILLIAM RAMSAY HONORED

HOWELL, LACROSSE MANAGER"

Honorary Degree of LL. D. Conferred on
British Chemist Before a Large
Audience Last Friday.

Rule Requiring Managers to Be Seniors
Disregarded at Meeting of Athletic
Board Last Monday.

The honorary degree of Doctor
of Laws was publicly conferred on
Sir William Ramsay in McCoy Hall
last Friday afternoon. Sir William
was presented for the degree by
Dean Griffin, secretary of the Academic Council, but contrary to custom, the speech of presentation was
made by President Remsen himself.
The President referred to his first
meeting with the illustrious British
scientist. In 1871 a young Scotchman came to the front door of the
chemical laboratory. at the University of Tubingen, and knocked. The
front door was not in general use,
entrance and egress being had by
the back one, but of this the young
stranger was ignorant. At length
President Remsen, then an assistant
in the laboratory, had his attention
attracted by the knocking, and with
his face and hands grimy from.the
coal with which he was working,
went to the door and opened it,
coming face to face for the first
time with William Ramsay.
The President then spoke briefly
of the achievements which since
that first meeting have brought the
'Young Scotchman fame and honors.
In the early nineties Lord Ramsay,
•in his experiments to determine the
weight of nitrogen, discovered that
the nitrogen of the air was slightly
heavier than that obtained from
other sources. This Ramsay showed
to be due to the presence of an
inert gas, which he called Argon;
and by this demonstration he first
came into world-wide prominence.
He has since discovered three other
rare inert gases in the atmosphere.
After what President Remsen _facetiously called "the radio-active period of chemistry" set in, Sir William was the first to call attention
to the fact that radium is constantly
disintegrating by sending out substances into the atmosphere; and
one of these substances, known as
Helium, he was the earliest to discover existing upon the earth.
These discoveries have a deep bearing upon the old problem of the
transmutation of elements; and the
President reminded his audience
that Sir William is at present engaged upon much the same problem as that which exercised the ingenuity of the alchemists.
After receiving the degree, Sir
William made a brief speech of
thanks, mentioning his kindly recollection of the long essays which
President Remsen used to make
him write at Tubingen, and expressing his gratification at being

RHODES EXAMINATIONS HELD

HOPKINS LOSES HARD GAME

Hopkins and St. John's Men Try for
Scholarship Getz, Brown, Niles and
Marshall Candidates.

Franklin and Mar:hall Victorious, But
Black and Blue Makes a Very Creditable Showing—Two Field Goals.

The examinations for the Rhodes
Scholarship from Maryland were
held in McCoy Hall last Tuesday
and Wednesday. The subjects covered were Latin grammar, translation from Latin into English, the
writing of Latin prose, Greek grammar, translation from the Greek,
the elements of algebra or geometry, and arithmetic. Four Hopkins students, William N. Brown,
'I 2 ; Emory H. Niles, '13; C. L.
Getz, '13, and J. H. Marshall, '13,
and two students from St. John's,
E. S. Crum and R. E. Staley, took
the examinations. These examinations were merely qualifying ; and
the student who made the best
showing in them will not for that
reason be awarded the scholarship.
A committee, of which President
Remsen is chairman, and Presidents Fell of St. John's, and Lewis
of Western Maryland, are the other
two members, will decide which of
the students who pass the examination has made the best record in
all branches of his college career,
student-activities as well as studies.
As four very capable Hopkins men
took :the examination, it does not
seem. likely that the scholarship will
be awarded to one of the other as
pirants: the race seems to be among
the Hopkins entrants. The committee will have an exceedingly
difficult and unpleasant task in
making its selectiqn.
Under the terms of the will of
Cecil Rhodes, three things are to
be taken into consideration in the
award of the scholarships: first,
scholastic excellence; second,"fondness for and devotion to" manly
sports; third, moral strength and

A meeting of the Athletic Board
was held in the Trophy Room on
Monday evening, October 14, to
complete the business held over
from the meeting of the week before.
"Dick" McCabe, who has been
helping to coach the football team
all season, was officially elected assistant coach. He will therefore
continue to supervise the work of
the squad, especially of the line
men. The team thus has two
coaches, the head coach, "Eddie"
Harlan, who is a star backfield
man, and "Dick" McCabe, for the
line.
Roger Howell, '14, was elected
manager of the lacrosse team for
this year. Howell has been assistant manager for one year under
John K, Burgan, whom he succeeds. He has also been a member
of the lacrosse squad.
The election of .Howell, who is
not a senior, is one more indication that the new rules adopted last
year for the guidance of the Athletic Board are only advisory. The
rules have already been disregarded
in the election of Getz as manager
of the baseball team and Carter
of the lacrosse team. These men are
both connected with the press in
violation of the rule which provides
that no undergraduate manager
shall have any connection with a
city paper. The disregard of the
rule which provides that all managers shall be seniors is therefore
not surprising in the case of the
lacrosse managership.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

Although defeated 1)\- Franklin
and Marshall, last Saturady, at
.Homewood, Jo to 3, the Hopkins
football team played much better
than in the preceding game, and no
one need feel any keen disappointment about the result. The game
was hard fought and a pretty one
to watch. The Black and Blue
eleven played true to form most of
the time, and forced the visitors to
extend themselves to their utmost.
Failure to block a long forward
pass in the fourth quarter cost
lopkins the game. A well thrown
pass from Jones to Sykes netted 20
yards for Franklin and Marshall,
and placed the pigskin on Hopkins'
eight-yard line. From this point
the Franklin and Mar-shall team
carried the ball across the line on
the third attempt. Hopkins made
a desperate stand in front of the
goal line, but the weight of the opposing team was too much for the
Black and Blue. Wood scored the
touchdown and kicked goal.
Gillett kicked a pretty field goal
from the 35-yard line early in the
first quarter. Jones, the Franklin
and Marshall fullback, tied the
score with a place kick from the
field in the second period. The
Lancastrians advanced the ball
dangerously near the Hopkins goal
line, but the Hopkins players succeeded in holding their heavier op
ponents for downs, and obtained
the ball on their two-yard line.
Gillett punted out of danger.
Play was about even in the third
period, though for a time Hopkins
made some headway with a succession of forward passes. Most of
the Hopkins attempts at forward _
passes were failures, but improvement could be noticed in the latter
part of the game, and it looks as
though Hopkins can develop a
strong attack if the players will
only become more familiar with the
open style of play.
Tappan showed up well at quarterback, and he is by far the most
satisfactory man Coach Harlan has
played at quarter this year, though
there is no pluckier player in the
squad than Johnnie Yost. Connolly worked hard in the Hopkins
line, and Branham was a strong
factor in the backfield, both on the
offense and defense.
(Continued on page 7, col. I.)

The next meeting of the Society,
which will be held on the thirtyfirst of this month, will be an arbitration meeting. According to a
provision in the constitution of the
Society, at least four arbitration
meetings must be held each year,
in order that the arbitration element
of the Society may not be lost. The
Hopkins Society is the oldest collegiate arbitration society in the
world. It was founded by Mr.
L. B. Bobbitt as an arbitration society exclusively, but added the
literary element last year. Mr.
J. S. Dickinson, '13, and Abel Wolman, '13, have charge of arranging the arbitration meeting of the
thirty-first.

these speeches were finished, the
meeting was thrown open to general discussion on the subject. The

Francis Key Murray, A. B. '10,
took a flying trip to England last
summer.
Benjamin F. Cator, A. B. '07,
who was formerly the legal representative of the American Bonding
Company on the Pacific Coast, has
returned to Baltimore.
Le Grand W. Perce, A. B. '10,
is in the real estate business in
Chicago. He is associated with his
brother under the firm name of
Hyde W. Perce & Co.
The present private secretary to
Mr. Justice Woods, of South Carolina, is Edward P. Guerard, Jr.,
A. B.'09. Mr. Guerard was admitted to the bar in South Carolina
last spring.
Advance advertising of The
Youth's Companion, a well known
Boston weekly paper published by
Perry. Mason Company, states that
sometime in 1913 will appear an
article written for them by President Remsen, entitled "What Science Is."
Two Hopkins men are among the
new appointees on the faculty of
Washington University. Theodore
W. Clocker, A. B. '03, fellow 'o6,
who was for some time head of the
Boston School of Social Economy,
will be professor of sociology. Dr.
Myers, another graduate of Hopkins, is to be in the department of
physiology.
Dear old "Billie" Haynes, ex-'12,
"ex-Professor Napoleon," is also in
the Windy City. He is in charge
of the Central States Branch(which
covers all the territory from Pennsylvania to the Rockies, north of
Tennessee and Arkansas) of D. 0.
Haynes, magazine publishers, New
York. Last winter he was in
charge of the Philadelphia office.
At a literary entertainment for
the benefit of the blind given at the
Library of Congress in Washington, on October 8, Dr. George C.
Keidel, A. B., Class of '89, read
selections from the old French love
story of "Ancassin and Nicolette."
The English translation of F. W.
Bourdillon was used. Dr. Keidel
received his Ph.D. degree in 1895,
after holding a fellowship from
1893 to 1895.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 21, 1912
The Rhodes Scholarships.

The examinations held last Tuesday and Wednesday should bring
home to us once more the splendid
generosity of the late Cecil Rhodes.
The Rhodes Scholarships are not
appreciated in this country as they
should be. The terms upon which
they are granted are misunderstood.
The advantages which they carry to
the recipient are not properly estimated. Many people think that the
purpose of the scholarships is to
pick up a husky American athlete,
and set him down to the study of
Greek grammar in a seat of learning three centuries behind the times.
Too often, perhaps, this has
seemed to be their result, but nothing could be further from their purpose.
As a matter of fact, the ideal for
which Oxford strives is the very
ideal which, more than any other,
is necessary in our American life
of today. The study of Greek
grammar or of Greek poetry even
is not the be-all and end-all of an
Oxford education; the whole aim
of that education is to impart a
broad culture and to cultivate a
thoughtful attitude toward the problems which surround us. Here in
America we all seem to have two
faults: We know some one thing
as well as it can be known, and
because of our complete mastery of
this one thing we feel competent to
make up our minds about all the
other things in the world in a moment. Half of the differences in
one political life arise from a blind
inability to perceive what the other
fellow stands for. In a democracy

there is nothing more essential than Most completeI FALL SUITINGS J- in the city now on

Hopkins Was the Ideal University.

In a recent article in the American
Educational Review, Dr. Albert
Shaw takes occasion to refer to
Hopkins in the following manner:
"It has, of course, never been true
that any of our colleges or universities regarded themselves as existing in order to create a selfishly
superior class of men, better able
to look out for themselves in their
professions, in their mastery over
economic forces and in their relationships with politics and government. But some of the tendencies
that have appeared in certain of
our colleges and universities have
seemed to be due to a failure to perceive clearly that such institutions
must be of broad service to the
whole community or else must suffer loss of power within themselves
to perform even their restricted
task.
"When an institution is carried
on in large part for the sake of
its own prestige and with regard to
the pleasures and social well-being
of its students it cannot express
tendencies toward luxury, selfishness, excess and vainglory. It must
know its task well, it must feel
its mission so strongly, that there
can be no room in it for the idler,
the mere dilettante or sybaritic son
of plutocracy. I remember the
early days of the Johns .Hopkins
University, for instance, when there
was such zeal for learning, such
devotion to scientific research, that
no idler could possibly have survived in its atmosphere."

October 19, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

DEAR SIR—Last year

THE NEws-

LETTER published several letters

stating reasons why there should
be a non-fraternity representative
on the Cotillon Board. However,
probably because of the fact that
non-fraternity representation was
not suggested until after the Board
had been definitely formed, no steps
were taken to bring it about. But,
now, we are yet to have the first
cotillon, and now seems to be the
time to suggest non-fraternity representation again.
It is in the hands of the fraternity men, I am told, to grant this
representation. That is, it is in the
hands of the Cotillon Board. One
vote against such representation, I
am also told, will be enough to reject it entirely. All six votes are
needed to welcome it. I, therefore,
write my letter for the fraternity
men, who influence these votes, and

especially for the members of the
Cotillon Board, and ask that the
question be carefully and earnestly
considered.
My reasons why the non-fraternity men should have a representative on the Cotillon Board are as
follows: In the first place, granting the non-fraternity men representation will be showing them
due courtesy. The cotillons are
dances for all the students and by
all the students. In other words,
they are Hopkins dances. They are
not fraternity dances. Moreover,
the non-fraternity men attend the
dances in large numbers. It is,
then, courtesy due the non-fraternity men that they be granted the
power of electing, on the board that
arranges the dances for all the students, one of their own number to
represent them.
In the second place, it is on the
grounds of justice, that the nonfraternity men should have this representation. On the one hand,
every single fraternity man who attends the Hopkins dances has, on
the board that arranges the dances,
a representative upon whose name
he has cast a vote. On the other
hand, although the non-fraternity
men who attend the dances are as
large in number as the 'members
from any one fraternity, yet they
have no representative at all. This
is a condition of affairs that is
manifestly not just.

I may, too, in the third place,
say that the cotillons, with the help
of non - fraternity representation,
will be more successful, in that they
will be more truly Hopkins dances;
for the extra man on the board
will be able to get subscriptions
from non - fraternity men more
readily than a fraternity man can,
just as a member of one fraternity
can get subscriptions from the
members of that fraternity more
readily than a person can who is a
member of another fraternity. The
probabilty is that most of a nonfraternity man's friends are among
non-fraternity men. In addition to
this, the non-fraternity men, who
will be indirectly helping to arrange
the cotillons, will be more personally interested in them and will attend them in Still larger numbers.
The cotillons will indeed be Hopkins dances.
Let me say, in conclusion, that I
am confident that there is, in almost
every Hopkins student, a high sense
of justice, courtesy and loyalty to
Hopkins. I am confident that when
a question is brought to his attention, which involves courtesy and
justice to his fellows, he will decide
it in a way that is right.
Yours truly,

The gymnasium class for the
freshmen will commence about November 1, under the direction of
Mr. Kistler. The class meets on
Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays,
from 5 to 6 P. M., and attendance
on it is compulsory for freshmen,
unless they are out for some 'varsity team.
After the Christmas holidays, the
members of the class are divided
into two teams—the Whites and the
Blues—and athletic and gymnastic
contests of various kinds are held.
"Chinning" and "dipping," potato
races, high jumping, broad jumping, and many other events are contested. Five points are given for
first place, three for second, and one
for third in all events but the big
relay race, in which every member
of the two teams runs. This race
counts ten points for the winning
team, and always arouses great enthusiasm.
At the end. of the gymnasium
season, bronze medals are awarded
to all the members of the team
which makes the most points and
a silver medal is given to the
man making the highest individual
record.
The entrance hall of the cage has
been freshened up with red and
white paint, and the gymnasium
floor has been newly painted, while
the apparatus has been put in excellent shape, so that the best results may be obtained, and the interest in the work bids fair to become more ardent this year than
ever before. With such a numerous
and husky freshman class, some
records are due to fall before the
season is over.
An ancient punster once remarked
that "some people will stand upon
a needle's point and argue about
a needless point."
In Samuel Sewall's Diary, under
April 3, 1708, we read the words:
"I went to Cous. Dumer's to see
his News-Letter." We have not
been aware of the age of our paper's
name!

With the intention of seeing
whether the impression voiced in
last week's editorial on "Freshman
Scholarships" would be verified by
the facts, Tim NEws-LErrER has
gathered during the past week
some interesting statistics as to the
age at which men enter Hopkins.
Complete statistics were not available, except in the case of the freshman class, for which they were kindly furnished by Registrar Ball. In
the classes of 1913 and 1914, figures enough were assembled to enable one to form certain conclusions
with regard to the question. No
figures at all were available for the
Class of 1915.
In the Class of 1913, fourteen of
the twenty-six men approached, had
entered college at the age of 18.
In the Class of 1914, thirteen out
of the thirty-four men approached,
had entered college at the age of
17. In the. freshman class, on the
other hand, the single age, including the largest number of men, was
18, as in the Class of 1913. Of the
men approached in the Class of
1913, two had entered college aged
20; fourteen, aged i8; five, aged 17;
one, aged 16; one aged 15. In the
Class of 1914, three at the time of
their entrance were 20, six were
19, seven were 18, thirteen were
17, and five were 16. Of the men
approached, this gives an average
entrance age of 18.1 for the Class
of 1913, of 17.6 for the Class of
1914. The average age in the
freshman class is 17.9.
One noteworthy fact, however, is
that the age of the matriculates in
the freshman class is uniformly below that of the candidates for matriculation. Among these men, indeed, the average was only 17.6,
as in the Class of 1914. It is the
non-matriculates who most frequently "drop out" in the progress
of a class through college, and it
is, therefore, probable that the average of entrance among the men who
form the Class of 1916—three years
from now—will be considerably
lower than the 17.9 years shown
today. At all events, as was stated
in the editorial, there is a considerable difference between the average
age of the men in '13 and of those
in '14, though hardly so great as
we expected. The freshmen, on
the other hand, have not the excuse
of premature juvenility for their
showing in the scholarship contest.

SIR WILLIAM RAMSAY HONORED

HOWELL, LACROSSE MANAGER"

Honorary Degree of LL. D. Conferred on
British Chemist Before a Large
Audience Last Friday.

Rule Requiring Managers to Be Seniors
Disregarded at Meeting of Athletic
Board Last Monday.

The honorary degree of Doctor
of Laws was publicly conferred on
Sir William Ramsay in McCoy Hall
last Friday afternoon. Sir William
was presented for the degree by
Dean Griffin, secretary of the Academic Council, but contrary to custom, the speech of presentation was
made by President Remsen himself.
The President referred to his first
meeting with the illustrious British
scientist. In 1871 a young Scotchman came to the front door of the
chemical laboratory. at the University of Tubingen, and knocked. The
front door was not in general use,
entrance and egress being had by
the back one, but of this the young
stranger was ignorant. At length
President Remsen, then an assistant
in the laboratory, had his attention
attracted by the knocking, and with
his face and hands grimy from.the
coal with which he was working,
went to the door and opened it,
coming face to face for the first
time with William Ramsay.
The President then spoke briefly
of the achievements which since
that first meeting have brought the
'Young Scotchman fame and honors.
In the early nineties Lord Ramsay,
•in his experiments to determine the
weight of nitrogen, discovered that
the nitrogen of the air was slightly
heavier than that obtained from
other sources. This Ramsay showed
to be due to the presence of an
inert gas, which he called Argon;
and by this demonstration he first
came into world-wide prominence.
He has since discovered three other
rare inert gases in the atmosphere.
After what President Remsen _facetiously called "the radio-active period of chemistry" set in, Sir William was the first to call attention
to the fact that radium is constantly
disintegrating by sending out substances into the atmosphere; and
one of these substances, known as
Helium, he was the earliest to discover existing upon the earth.
These discoveries have a deep bearing upon the old problem of the
transmutation of elements; and the
President reminded his audience
that Sir William is at present engaged upon much the same problem as that which exercised the ingenuity of the alchemists.
After receiving the degree, Sir
William made a brief speech of
thanks, mentioning his kindly recollection of the long essays which
President Remsen used to make
him write at Tubingen, and expressing his gratification at being

A meeting of the Athletic Board
was held in the Trophy Room on
Monday evening, October 14, to
complete the business held over
from the meeting of the week before.
"Dick" McCabe, who has been
helping to coach the football team
all season, was officially elected assistant coach. He will therefore
continue to supervise the work of
the squad, especially of the line
men. The team thus has two
coaches, the head coach, "Eddie"
Harlan, who is a star backfield
man, and "Dick" McCabe, for the
line.
Roger Howell, '14, was elected
manager of the lacrosse team for
this year. Howell has been assistant manager for one year under
John K, Burgan, whom he succeeds. He has also been a member
of the lacrosse squad.
The election of .Howell, who is
not a senior, is one more indication that the new rules adopted last
year for the guidance of the Athletic Board are only advisory. The
rules have already been disregarded
in the election of Getz as manager
of the baseball team and Carter
of the lacrosse team. These men are
both connected with the press in
violation of the rule which provides
that no undergraduate manager
shall have any connection with a
city paper. The disregard of the
rule which provides that all managers shall be seniors is therefore
not surprising in the case of the
lacrosse managership.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

Although defeated 1)\- Franklin
and Marshall, last Saturady, at
.Homewood, Jo to 3, the Hopkins
football team played much better
than in the preceding game, and no
one need feel any keen disappointment about the result. The game
was hard fought and a pretty one
to watch. The Black and Blue
eleven played true to form most of
the time, and forced the visitors to
extend themselves to their utmost.
Failure to block a long forward
pass in the fourth quarter cost
lopkins the game. A well thrown
pass from Jones to Sykes netted 20
yards for Franklin and Marshall,
and placed the pigskin on Hopkins'
eight-yard line. From this point
the Franklin and Mar-shall team
carried the ball across the line on
the third attempt. Hopkins made
a desperate stand in front of the
goal line, but the weight of the opposing team was too much for the
Black and Blue. Wood scored the
touchdown and kicked goal.
Gillett kicked a pretty field goal
from the 35-yard line early in the
first quarter. Jones, the Franklin
and Marshall fullback, tied the
score with a place kick from the
field in the second period. The
Lancastrians advanced the ball
dangerously near the Hopkins goal
line, but the Hopkins players succeeded in holding their heavier op
ponents for downs, and obtained
the ball on their two-yard line.
Gillett punted out of danger.
Play was about even in the third
period, though for a time Hopkins
made some headway with a succession of forward passes. Most of
the Hopkins attempts at forward _
passes were failures, but improvement could be noticed in the latter
part of the game, and it looks as
though Hopkins can develop a
strong attack if the players will
only become more familiar with the
open style of play.
Tappan showed up well at quarterback, and he is by far the most
satisfactory man Coach Harlan has
played at quarter this year, though
there is no pluckier player in the
squad than Johnnie Yost. Connolly worked hard in the Hopkins
line, and Branham was a strong
factor in the backfield, both on the
offense and defense.

The Rhodes Scholarships.

The examinations held last Tuesday and Wednesday should bring
home to us once more the splendid
generosity of the late Cecil Rhodes.
The Rhodes Scholarships are not
appreciated in this country as they
should be. The terms upon which
they are granted are misunderstood.
The advantages which they carry to
the recipient are not properly estimated. Many people think that the
purpose of the scholarships is to
pick up a husky American athlete,
and set him down to the study of
Greek grammar in a seat of learning three centuries behind the times.
Too often, perhaps, this has
seemed to be their result, but nothing could be further from their purpose.
As a matter of fact, the ideal for
which Oxford strives is the very
ideal which, more than any other,
is necessary in our American life
of today. The study of Greek
grammar or of Greek poetry even
is not the be-all and end-all of an
Oxford education; the whole aim
of that education is to impart a
broad culture and to cultivate a
thoughtful attitude toward the problems which surround us. Here in
America we all seem to have two
faults: We know some one thing
as well as it can be known, and
because of our complete mastery of
this one thing we feel competent to
make up our minds about all the
other things in the world in a moment. Half of the differences in

Hopkins Was the Ideal University.

In a recent article in the American
Educational Review, Dr. Albert
Shaw takes occasion to refer to
Hopkins in the following manner:
"It has, of course, never been true
that any of our colleges or universities regarded themselves as existing in order to create a selfishly
superior class of men, better able
to look out for themselves in their
professions, in their mastery over
economic forces and in their relationships with politics and government. But some of the tendencies
that have appeared in certain of
our colleges and universities have
seemed to be due to a failure to perceive clearly that such institutions
must be of broad service to the
whole community or else must suffer loss of power within themselves
to perform even their restricted
task.
"When an institution is carried
on in large part for the sake of
its own prestige and with regard to
the pleasures and social well-being
of its students it cannot express
tendencies toward luxury, selfishness, excess and vainglory. It must
know its task well, it must feel
its mission so strongly, that there
can be no room in it for the idler,
the mere dilettante or sybaritic son
of plutocracy. I remember the
early days of the Johns .Hopkins
University, for instance, when there
was such zeal for learning, such
devotion to scientific research, that
no idler could possibly have survived in its atmosphere."

October 19, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

DEAR SIR—Last year

THE NEws-

LETTER published several letters

stating reasons why there should
be a non-fraternity representative
on the Cotillon Board. However,
probably because of the fact that
non-fraternity representation was
not suggested until after the Board
had been definitely formed, no steps
were taken to bring it about. But,
now, we are yet to have the first
cotillon, and now seems to be the
time to suggest non-fraternity representation again.
It is in the hands of the fraternity men, I am told, to grant this
representation. That is, it is in the
hands of the Cotillon Board. One
vote against such representation, I
am also told, will be enough to reject it entirely. All six votes are
needed to welcome it. I, therefore,
write my letter for the fraternity
men, who influence these votes, and

especially for the members of the
Cotillon Board, and ask that the
question be carefully and earnestly
considered.
My reasons why the non-fraternity men should have a representative on the Cotillon Board are as
follows: In the first place, granting the non-fraternity men representation will be showing them
due courtesy. The cotillons are
dances for all the students and by
all the students. In other words,
they are Hopkins dances. They are
not fraternity dances. Moreover,
the non-fraternity men attend the
dances in large numbers. It is,
then, courtesy due the non-fraternity men that they be granted the
power of electing, on the board that
arranges the dances for all the students, one of their own number to
represent them.
In the second place, it is on the
grounds of justice, that the nonfraternity men should have this representation. On the one hand,
every single fraternity man who attends the Hopkins dances has, on
the board that arranges the dances,
a representative upon whose name
he has cast a vote. On the other
hand, although the non-fraternity
men who attend the dances are as
large in number as the 'members
from any one fraternity, yet they
have no representative at all. This
is a condition of affairs that is
manifestly not just.

I may, too, in the third place,
say that the cotillons, with the help
of non - fraternity representation,
will be more successful, in that they
will be more truly Hopkins dances;
for the extra man on the board
will be able to get subscriptions
from non - fraternity men more
readily than a fraternity man can,
just as a member of one fraternity
can get subscriptions from the
members of that fraternity more
readily than a person can who is a
member of another fraternity. The
probabilty is that most of a nonfraternity man's friends are among
non-fraternity men. In addition to
this, the non-fraternity men, who
will be indirectly helping to arrange
the cotillons, will be more personally interested in them and will attend them in Still larger numbers.
The cotillons will indeed be Hopkins dances.
Let me say, in conclusion, that I
am confident that there is, in almost
every Hopkins student, a high sense
of justice, courtesy and loyalty to
Hopkins. I am confident that when
a question is brought to his attention, which involves courtesy and
justice to his fellows, he will decide
it in a way that is right.
Yours truly,

The gymnasium class for the
freshmen will commence about November 1, under the direction of
Mr. Kistler. The class meets on
Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays,
from 5 to 6 P. M., and attendance
on it is compulsory for freshmen,
unless they are out for some 'varsity team.
After the Christmas holidays, the
members of the class are divided
into two teams—the Whites and the
Blues—and athletic and gymnastic
contests of various kinds are held.
"Chinning" and "dipping," potato
races, high jumping, broad jumping, and many other events are contested. Five points are given for
first place, three for second, and one
for third in all events but the big
relay race, in which every member
of the two teams runs. This race
counts ten points for the winning
team, and always arouses great enthusiasm.
At the end. of the gymnasium
season, bronze medals are awarded
to all the members of the team
which makes the most points and
a silver medal is given to the
man making the highest individual
record.
The entrance hall of the cage has
been freshened up with red and
white paint, and the gymnasium
floor has been newly painted, while
the apparatus has been put in excellent shape, so that the best results may be obtained, and the interest in the work bids fair to become more ardent this year than
ever before. With such a numerous
and husky freshman class, some
records are due to fall before the
season is over.
An ancient punster once remarked
that "some people will stand upon
a needle's point and argue about
a needless point."
In Samuel Sewall's Diary, under
April 3, 1708, we read the words:
"I went to Cous. Dumer's to see
his News-Letter." We have not
been aware of the age of our paper's
name!

Saturday's Games.
Swarthmore, 21 ; Navy, 6.
Stevens, o; Rensalaer, 7.
St. John's, 14; W. and L., 24.
Western Md., 0; V. P. I., 44.
Galaudet, 38; B. C. C., 22.
19; U. of Va., o.
V. M.
The teams which I lopkins meet
the remainder of the season figured
in Saturday's games according to
the scores in the table above. Of
the six teams, three won their
games, one being Galaudet, which
played Baltimore City College, a
team much lighter and younger,
and only won after 22 points had
been scored against her. That
leaves only two teams which won
creditable victories — Swarthmore
and Virginia Military Institute.
Swarthmore beat the Navy after
the Navy had scored a touchdown
within the first five minutes of the
opening quarter. Th2 Middies,
thereafter, could do not!lino- to
withstand the well-drilled attack of
Swarthmore
the Quaker lads.
seems to be the surprise this year
among the smaller college teams.
The 'Varsity plays Stevens in two
weeks. Saturday's defeat for this
team is the fourth of the season,
two of which were large-score
games with Princeton and West
Point.
St. John's fought a stubborn battle against Washington and Lee.
The score was tied at 14 points
each, when Washington and Lee
forged ahead in the last two
quarters, and won out by ten points.
St. John's has a team which has
fought just as hard in each previous battle this year, arid trimmed
the Franklin and Marshall team
which beat the 'Varsity on Saturday, though at the time the Pennsylvanians were in a crippled condition.
Western Maryland continues to
play a wretched game. Her behavior in the game Saturday against
Virginia Polytechnic Institute was
full of blunders and poor playing,
consequently, Virginia Polytechnic
Institute rolled up a score of 44
to o.
Virginia Military Academy, which
comes to Homewood for the first
time on Thanksgiving Day,trounced
the University of Virginia, 19 to
o. The Baltimore papers give
merely the score of the game,
though one can imagine that Virginia Military Institute must have
a strong team to beat Virginia, unless the Virginia team is much
worse than last year's combination.

Average Age of Entrance Determined for
Various Classes-1913 Showed 18.1;
1914, 17.6, and 1916, 17.9.

With the intention of seeing
whether the impression voiced in
last week's editorial on "Freshman
Scholarships" would be verified by
the facts, Tim NEws-LErrER has
gathered during the past week
some interesting statistics as to the
age at which men enter Hopkins.
Complete statistics were not available, except in the case of the freshman class, for which they were kindly furnished by Registrar Ball. In
the classes of 1913 and 1914, figures enough were assembled to enable one to form certain conclusions
with regard to the question. No
figures at all were available for the
Class of 1915.
In the Class of 1913, fourteen of
the twenty-six men approached, had
entered college at the age of 18.
In the Class of 1914, thirteen out
of the thirty-four men approached,
had entered college at the age of
17. In the. freshman class, on the
other hand, the single age, including the largest number of men, was
18, as in the Class of 1913. Of the
men approached in the Class of
1913, two had entered college aged
20; fourteen, aged i8; five, aged 17;
one, aged 16; one aged 15. In the
Class of 1914, three at the time of
their entrance were 20, six were
19, seven were 18, thirteen were
17, and five were 16. Of the men
approached, this gives an average
entrance age of 18.1 for the Class
of 1913, of 17.6 for the Class of
1914. The average age in the
freshman class is 17.9.
One noteworthy fact, however, is
that the age of the matriculates in
the freshman class is uniformly below that of the candidates for matriculation. Among these men, indeed, the average was only 17.6,
as in the Class of 1914. It is the
non-matriculates who most frequently "drop out" in the progress
of a class through college, and it
is, therefore, probable that the average of entrance among the men who
form the Class of 1916—three years
from now—will be considerably
lower than the 17.9 years shown
today. At all events, as was stated
in the editorial, there is a considerable difference between the average
age of the men in '13 and of those
in '14, though hardly so great as
we expected. The freshmen, on
the other hand, have not the excuse
of premature juvenility for their
showing in the scholarship contest.
